The_Highwomen:
{{short description|American country group}} {{shortlead|date=April 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = The Highwomen | image = {{multiple image|border=infobox|perrow = 2|total_width=200| caption_align = center| image_style = border:1; | image1 = Brandi Carlile - Seattle (cropped).jpg | caption1 = [[Brandi Carlile]] | image2 = Natalie Hemby.JPG | caption2 = [[Natalie Hemby]] | image3 = Maren Morris 2019 by Glenn Francis.jpg | caption3 = [[Maren Morris]] | image4 = Amanda Shires 2016.jpg | caption4 = [[Amanda Shires]] }} | image_size = | image_upright = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | alias = | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Country music|Country]] * [[Americana (music)|Americana]] }} | years_active = {{start date|2019}}–present | label = [[Elektra Records|Elektra]] | website = {{URL|thehighwomen.com}} | current_members = * [[Brandi Carlile]] * [[Natalie Hemby]] * [[Maren Morris]] * [[Amanda Shires]] | past members = }} '''The Highwomen''' is an American [[country music]] [[supergroup (music)|supergroup]]{{cite magazine|last1=Moss|first1=Marissa R.|title=The Highwomen: In the Studio With Country's Ballsiest New Group|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/the-highwomen-interview-brandi-carlile-maren-morris-860629/|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=19 July 2019|language=en-US|access-date=19 July 2019|archive-date=20 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200820074821/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/the-highwomen-interview-brandi-carlile-maren-morris-860629/|url-status=live}}{{cite news|last1=Weiner|first1=Natalie|title=Country Music Is a Man's World. The Highwomen Want to Change That.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/03/arts/music/highwomen-country-supergroup.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=3 September 2019|access-date=4 September 2019|archive-date=2 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200902100144/https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/03/arts/music/highwomen-country-supergroup.html|url-status=live}} composed of [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Natalie Hemby]], [[Maren Morris]], and [[Amanda Shires]].{{cite magazine|last1=Hughes|first1=Hilary|title=Brandi Carlile, Maren Morris, Amanda Shires & Natalie Hemby Unpack The Highwomen's Impact|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8527897/the-highwomen-interview-brandi-carlile-maren-morris-amanda-shires-album|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=23 August 2019|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-date=7 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907190206/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8527897/the-highwomen-interview-brandi-carlile-maren-morris-amanda-shires-album|url-status=live}} Formed in 2019,{{cite magazine|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Brandi Carlile, Maren Morris Talk Highwomen Project|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-brandi-carlile-maren-morris-amanda-shires-natalie-hemby-847032/|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|language=en-US|date=11 June 2019|format=Includes two-part audio interview on [[SiriusXM]]'s channel [[The Highway (Sirius XM)|The Highway]] with [[Storme Warren]]|access-date=19 July 2019|archive-date=7 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907190211/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-brandi-carlile-maren-morris-amanda-shires-natalie-hemby-847032/|url-status=live}} the group's [[The Highwomen (album)|self-titled debut album]] was released on September 6 of the same year by [[Elektra Records]] and was produced by [[Dave Cobb]].{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Stephen|title=Listen: Brandi Carlile, Maren Morris, Amanda Shires, Natalie Hemby Are The Highwomen|url=https://www.npr.org/2019/07/19/743192244/brandi-carlile-maren-morris-and-others-release-their-first-single-as-the-highwom|work=[[NPR]]|date=19 July 2019|language=en|access-date=19 July 2019|archive-date=7 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907190215/https://www.npr.org/2019/07/19/743192244/brandi-carlile-maren-morris-and-others-release-their-first-single-as-the-highwom|url-status=live}} ==History== In 2016, when Shires was finishing her record ''My Piece of Land'' in music producer [[Dave Cobb]]'s studio, Shires had an idea to create a female country supergroup in homage to the legendary [[The Highwaymen (country supergroup)|Highwaymen]] country supergroup (consisting of [[Johnny Cash]], [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Kris Kristofferson]] and [[Willie Nelson]]). At the same time, the lack of representation of women artists on country music radio and at country music festivals had been publicly discussed by many, influenced by the [[MeToo movement]] and journalists like Marissa Moss. While on tour in her van, listening to country radio, Shires kept a running list of artists and noticed that there were few women. When she called to request they play more women artists, she was directed to a Facebook page lottery system. Cobb recommended Shires call Carlile, whom she didn't know. Carlile thought it would be fun, and would be an interesting creative project. The Highwomen project was widely hinted at by Carlile, Morris and Shires before it was officially announced on April 6, 2019. With the name paying homage to The Highwaymen, the Highwomen were originally intended to leave the fourth spot in their line-up vacant to allow other female collaborators to join them, with [[Chely Wright]], [[Courtney Marie Andrews]], [[Margo Price]], [[Janelle Monáe]] and [[Sheryl Crow]] mentioned as potential guests.{{cite news|first1=Chris|last1=Willman|title=Brandi Carlile, Amanda Shires Add Maren Morris to 'Highwomen' Supergroup|url=https://variety.com/2019/music/news/brandi-carline-maren-morris-amanda-shires-highwomen-supergroup-1203156171/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=6 March 2019|access-date=19 July 2019|archive-date=8 June 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190608235415/https://variety.com/2019/music/news/brandi-carline-maren-morris-amanda-shires-highwomen-supergroup-1203156171/|url-status=live}} The band, who jokingly refer to the collaboration as a pirate ship experience, said that they see the project as an incubator project that highlights mentorship and support of fellow women artists. Morris hadn't worked with Cobb before, and remarked on how much she liked tracking live. The band recorded live vocals, live band, harmonies in unison, where the musicians were recording together live in an organic environment at historic [[RCA Studio A]], which Cobb now owns. As part of the experience, some of the members got matching Highwomen tattoos.{{cite news|last1=McCartney|first1=Kelly|title=Inside the Making and the Movement of The Highwomen|url=https://www.nodepression.com/inside-the-making-and-the-movement-of-the-highwomen/|work=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]|date=9 September 2019|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-date=9 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190909060846/https://www.nodepression.com/inside-the-making-and-the-movement-of-the-highwomen/|url-status=live}} The group made their live debut on April 1, 2019 at [[Loretta Lynn]]'s 87th birthday concert held at the [[Bridgestone Arena]] in [[Nashville]]. There, [[Natalie Hemby]] was officially revealed as the final member and the quartet performed "[[It Wasn't God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels]]".{{cite magazine|first1=Marissa R.|last1=Moss|title=See the Highwomen's Live Debut at Loretta Lynn Birthday Show|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-brandi-carlile-loretta-lynn-birthday-concert-816499/|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=2 April 2019|access-date=19 July 2019|archive-date=5 April 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190405162535/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-brandi-carlile-loretta-lynn-birthday-concert-816499/|url-status=live}} Their debut single, "Redesigning Women", and its associated music video featuring female artists including [[Tanya Tucker]], [[Cam (singer)|Cam]], [[Lauren Alaina]], [[Cassadee Pope]] and [[Wynonna Judd]] was released on 19 July 2019, with their [[The Highwomen (album)|self-titled debut album]] (set for release on September 6) becoming available for pre-order on the same day.{{cite news|first1=Cillea|last1=Houghton|title=The Highwomen Light the Ultimate Bonfire in 'Redesigning Women' Video [Watch]|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/the-highwomen-redesigning-women-video/|work=[[Taste of Country]]|date=19 July 2019|access-date=19 July 2019|archive-date=7 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907223124/https://tasteofcountry.com/the-highwomen-redesigning-women-video/|url-status=live}} The song was promoted by country singer [[Dierks Bentley]] who released a comedic reading of the lyrics to his [[YouTube Channel]] which received praise from Carlile and Morris.{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Gayle|title=Dierks Bentley Does Comedic Reading of The Highwomen's 'Redesigning Women'|url=https://popculture.com/country-music/2019/07/24/dierks-bentley-comedic-reading-the-highwomen-redesigning-women/|work=PopCulture.com|date=24 July 2019|access-date=26 July 2019|archive-date=26 July 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190726155541/https://popculture.com/country-music/2019/07/24/dierks-bentley-comedic-reading-the-highwomen-redesigning-women/|url-status=live}} Their second single, "Crowded Table", written by band member Hemby and [[Lori McKenna]], was released on July 26, 2019.{{cite news|last1=Newcomb|first1=Ming Lee|title=Country supergroup The Highwomen share second single "Crowded Table": Stream|url=https://consequence.net/2019/07/the-highwomen-crowded-table-stream/|work=[[Consequence of Sound]]|date=26 July 2019|access-date=2 September 2019|archive-date=27 July 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190727170940/https://consequence.net/2019/07/the-highwomen-crowded-table-stream/|url-status=live}} In July 2019, the Highwomen performed their first ever full live set at the 60th annual [[Newport Folk Festival]], previewing songs from their upcoming album including "If She Ever Leaves Me", written by Shires, her husband [[Jason Isbell]] and Chris Thompkins.{{cite news|last1=Willman|first1=Chris|title=Country Supergroup the Highwomen Has a High Time in Newport Folk Festival Debut|url=https://variety.com/2019/music/news/highwomen-live-debut-newport-folk-festival-1203282123/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=27 July 2019|language=en|access-date=7 September 2019|archive-date=2 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190802063329/https://variety.com/2019/music/news/highwomen-live-debut-newport-folk-festival-1203282123/|url-status=live}} With Carlile on lead vocals, Isbell described it as "the first gay country song" which elicited applause from the audience. Other songs performed included "My Only Child", an ode to "suburban moms" performed by Hemby who wrote the track with Shires and [[Miranda Lambert]], "Loose Change", a nod to 70s country written by Morris, [[Daniel Layus]] of [[Augustana (band)|Augustana]], and [[Maggie Chapman (singer)|Maggie Chapman]], featuring Morris on lead vocals and "Cocktail and a Song" which was written solely by Shires in honor of her father. Carlile later invited the rest of the Highwomen to join her during her headlining set where, as they originally intended, the group performed alongside other female artists including [[Amy Ray]], [[Courtney Marie Andrews]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Jade Bird]], [[Judy Collins]], [[Linda Perry]], [[Lucy Dacus]], Our Native Daughters, [[Sheryl Crow]], The First Ladies of Bluegrass, and [[Yola Carter]].{{cite magazine|last1=Bernstein|first1=Jonathan|last2=Exposito|first2=Suzy|title=Newport Folk Festival 2019: 10 Best Things We Saw|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-live-reviews/newport-folk-fest-2019-recap-864579/|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=29 July 2019|access-date=29 July 2019|archive-date=29 July 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190729215835/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-live-reviews/newport-folk-fest-2019-recap-864579/|url-status=live}}{{cite magazine|last1=Hughes|first1=Hilary|title=The 10 Best Moments From the Surprise-Packed 2019 Newport Folk Festival|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/festivals/8524203/newport-folk-festival-2019-best-moments-dolly-parton-kermit-brandi-carlile|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=29 July 2019|access-date=29 July 2019|archive-date=29 July 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190729220553/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/festivals/8524203/newport-folk-festival-2019-best-moments-dolly-parton-kermit-brandi-carlile|url-status=live}} Shires said the plan was always to debut their music at Newport with Dolly Parton. The band wore custom suits by [[Manuel Cuevas|Manuel]]. Their cover of "[[The Chain (Fleetwood Mac song)|The Chain]]" by [[Fleetwood Mac]] from the soundtrack of the movie ''[[The Kitchen (2019 film)|The Kitchen]]'' debuted during the film's first trailer and was officially released on August 2, 2019.{{cite news|last1=Arcand|first1=Rob|title=New Music: The Highwomen Cover Fleetwood Mac's "The Chain": Listen|url=https://www.spin.com/2019/08/the-highwomen-cover-fleetwood-mac-the-chain-listen/|work=[[Spin (magazine)|SPIN]]|date=2 August 2019|access-date=13 August 2019|archive-date=9 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190809054027/https://www.spin.com/2019/08/the-highwomen-cover-fleetwood-mac-the-chain-listen/|url-status=live}} The title track of their self-titled debut album was released on August 13, 2019. Written by Carlile and Shires with [[Jimmy Webb]], the original writer of "[[Highwayman (song)|Highwayman]]", the track that originally inspired the Highwomen's formation, it tells the story of various women throughout history and features guest vocals from British country soul singer [[Yola Carter]] and backing vocals from [[Sheryl Crow]].{{cite magazine|last1=Hudak|first1=Joseph|title=Hear the Highwomen's Gender-Swapping Remake of the Highwaymen's Theme Song|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-highwayman-song-brandi-carlile-871074/|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=13 August 2019|access-date=13 August 2019|archive-date=13 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190813181542/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/highwomen-highwayman-song-brandi-carlile-871074/|url-status=live}} The song is a classic answer song. The band recorded 15 songs, but only 12 tracks made it on the album. Songwriters included the aforementioned [[Jimmy Webb]], [[Rodney Clawson]], [[Maggie Chapman (singer)|Maggie Chapman]], [[Lori McKenna]], [[Jason Isbell]], Peter Levin, [[Miranda Lambert]], [[Ray LaMontagne]], among many others.{{cite magazine|last1=Moss|first1=Marissa R.|title=The Highwomen's Debut Album: Track-by-Track Guide|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/the-highwomens-debut-album-track-by-track-guide-879785/|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=4 September 2019|access-date=6 September 2019|archive-date=6 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190906031247/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/the-highwomens-debut-album-track-by-track-guide-879785/|url-status=live}} Many of the songs flip gender roles, with additions of characters like refugee, preacher, Freedom Rider, and a healer, compared to the characters drawn by the Highwaymen songs.{{cite news|last1=Domenghini|first1=Annalise|title=The Highwomen On Feminism, Success, And Dolly Parton|url=https://nylon.com/the-highwomen-interview-dolly-parton|work=[[Nylon (magazine)|NYLON]]|date=6 September 2019|language=en|access-date=6 September 2019|archive-date=4 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191104164602/https://nylon.com/the-highwomen-interview-dolly-parton|url-status=live}} Following the release of their album, the band have infrequently performed together. In 2022, they performed "[[Somewhere Down The Road (Amy Grant song)|Somewhere Down The Road]]" at the [[Kennedy Center Honors]] in tribute to [[Amy Grant]], who was one of the honorees. They also performed "[[Coal Miner's Daughter (song)|Coal Miner's Daughter]]" during a tribute show on [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] following the death of [[Loretta Lynn]], with [[Brittney Spencer]] standing in for Morris.{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/highwomen-amy-grant-2022-kennedy-center-honors/ | title=WATCH: The Highwomen Tribute Amy Grant at Kennedy Center Honors | date=29 December 2022 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.vulture.com/2022/10/loretta-lynn-tribute-performances-jack-white-highwomen.html | title=Jack White, the Highwomen Pay Tribute to Loretta Lynn at the Grand Ole Opry | date=31 October 2022 }} ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" scope="col"| Title ! rowspan="2" scope="col"| Details ! colspan="7" scope="col"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" scope="col"| Sales |- ! scope="col"| [[Billboard 200|US]]
